Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing the time slip away. My girlfriend and I have been looking forward to tonight all week—our only free evening before I leave for a work trip. She’s already at the restaurant, texting me updates about the table, the menu, the candle she picked out. I promised I’d be there on time, that nothing would get in the way. But here I am, standing in a crowded polling station, clutching my ID as an official explains that my registration doesn’t match. If I want my vote to count, I have to fill out a provisional ballot, and the station closes in ten minutes. The form is long, the line is slow, and my heart pounds with guilt. I know how much tonight means to her, but I also know how important it is to vote, to do it right, to follow every instruction. I can’t be in two places at once, and the weight of both promises presses down on me as I stare at the form, torn between the person I love and the duty I believe in.
